message.content:
We first calculate the Free Cash Flow (FCF) as the net cash flow generated by operating activities minus any cash used for capital expenditures. In our cash flow statement, the operating activities produced a net flow of –17,417,367.15 and there was no cash used for purchasing fixed assets (the investing section shows “–0.00”). Therefore, the FCF is:

  FCF = –17,417,367.15 – 0 = –17,417,367.15

Next, to compute the Current Assets Turnover Ratio we use the formula:

  Current Assets Turnover Ratio = (Main Business Revenue) / (Average Current Assets)

The balance sheet shows that the current assets were 20,000,000.00 at the beginning (2023-12-31) and 21,224,639.20 at the end (2024-02-05). The average current assets would be:

  Average Current Assets = (20,000,000.00 + 21,224,639.20) / 2 = 20,612,319.60

The income statement gives Main Business Revenue = 14,542,813.42. Thus:

  Current Assets Turnover Ratio = 14,542,813.42 / 20,612,319.60 ≈ 0.7054

Rounded to two decimal places, the ratio is approximately 0.71.

We now present our answer in the requested format:

{
  "solution": {
    "Free Cash Flow (FCF)": "-17417367.15",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.71"
  }
}
